data.title: Famous People Born in 1890
data.meta_description: Celebrate the birthdays of 269 famous people, historical figures and celebrities born in 1890 like Dwight D. Eisenhower, Charles de Gaulle and Ho Chi Minh.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 269

Alice Tissot, French actress (Italian Straw Hat), born in Paris, France (d. 1971)

Jan 1 Anton Melik, Slovenian geographer (d. 1966)

Jan 1 Florence Lawrence, Canadian silent screen actress (Confidence), born in Hamilton, Ontario (d. 1938)

Mosa Pijade, Yugoslavian communist politician who worked with Tito, born in Belgrade, Serbia (d. 1957)

Cora Witherspoon, American actress (Quality Street The Bank Dick), born in New Orleans, Louisiana (d. 1957)

Henny Porten, German silent screen star (Deception), born in Magdeburg, Germany (d. 1960)

Maurice McLoughlin

American tennis player (US Nat C'ship 1912-13), born in Carson City, Nevada

Sandor Rado, Hungarian-American psychoanalyst, born in Kisvárda, Hungary (d. 1972)

Karel Čapek

Czech writer, playwright and critic (R.U.R.); coined the word "robot", born in Malé Svatoňovice, Hungary

Kurt Tucholsky, German journalist and writer (Panther Tiger & Co), born in Berlin, Germany (d. 1935)

Arthur O'Hara Wood, Australian tennis player (Australasian C'ship 1913), born in Melbourne, Australia (d. 1918)

Jan 10 Douglas MacLean, American silent film comedian/producer (Going Up), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 1967)

Jan 10 Ernest Milton, American actor (Cat Girl, Fiddler's Three), born in San Francisco, California (d. 1974)

Jan 10 Grigory Landsberg, Soviet physicist, born in Vologda, Russia (d. 1957)

Max Carey, American Baseball Hall of Fame outfielder (World Series 1925; 10 × NL stolen base leader; Pittsburgh Pirates, Brooklyn Robins) and manager (Brooklyn Dodgers), born in Terre Haute, Indiana (d. 1976)

Jan 11 Oswald de Andrade, Brazilian author (one of the modernist Group of Five), born in São Paulo, Brazil (d. 1954)

Mordecai Wyatt Johnson, American pastor and educator, born in Paris, Tennessee (d. 1976)

Jüri Uluots, Estonian Prime Minister (d. 1945)

Karl Freund, German cinematographer and film director (Dracula; I Love Lucy; The Mummy), born in Dvůr Králové (Königinhof), Bohemia, Austria-Hungarian Empire (d. 1969)

Jan 16 Lloyd Bacon, American actor (Charlie Chaplin films), born in San Jose, California (d. 1955)

Fred M. Vinson, American Democratic politician, US Treasury Secretary (1945-46) and the 13th Chief Justice of US Supreme Court (1946-53), born in Louisa, Kentucky (d. 1953)

Jan 22 Vinko Zganec, Croatian ethnomusicologist, born in Vratišinec, Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia (d. 1976)

Charles Scribner III, American book publisher, born in New York City (d. 1952)

Robert Stroud, American murderer, convict, and ornithologist dubbed "Birdman of Alcatraz", born in Seattle Washington (d. 1963)

Marguerite Canal, French conductor and composer (1st woman in France to conduct an orchestra), born in Toulouse, France (d. 1978)

Adolf Bach, German language professor and sociologist (Deutsche Namenkunde) (d. 1972)

Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, French general (WWII, Indo-China), born in Mouilleron-en-Pareds, France (d. 1952)

Charles Correll, American radio comedian (Amos 'n' Andy), born in Preoria, Illinois (d. 1972)

Feb 3 Larry MacPhail, American Baseball Hall of Fame executive (Cincinnati Reds, Brooklyn Dodgers, New York Yankees), born in Cass City, Michigan (d. 1975)

Claro Mayo Recto, Filipino politician, nationalist (opponent of US colonialism) and poet, born in Tiaong, Philippines (d. 1960)

Jacobus Oud, Dutch architect (De Stijl movement), born in Purmerend, Netherlands (d. 1963)

Boris Pasternak

Russian novelist and poet (Doctor Zhivago, Nobel 1958), born in Moscow, Russia

Cor Ruys, Dutch actor (Princess Stage, The Cross-Patch), born in Amsterdam, Noord-Holland, Netherlands (d. 1952)

Feb 10 Fanny Kaplan, failed assassin of Vladimir Lenin (d. 1918)

David Drummond, Australian politician (d. 1965)

Feb 11 Jan de Vries, Dutch scholar of Germanic linguistics and Germanic mythology, born in Amsterdam (d. 1964)

Nina Hamnett, Welsh artist and writer, born in Tenby, Pembrokeshire, Wales (d. 1956)

Robert Ley, German Nazi politician, born in Niederbreidenbach, Germany (d. 1945)

Feb 15 Semyon Bogatyrev, Russian and Soviet musicologist and composer (completed a symphony abandoned by Piotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky), born in Kharkiv, Ukraine, Russian Empire (d. 1960)

Adolphe Menjou, American actor (Front Page; Star is Born), born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania (d. 1963)

Feb 18 Edward Arnold, American actor (Mr Smith Goes to Washington), born in New York City (d. 1956)

Feb 18 Lauri Haarla, Finnish writer (Juudas, Sukeltaja), born in Korpilahti, Finland (d. 1944)

Sam Rice, American Baseball HOF outfielder (World Series 1924; AL stolen base leader 1920; Washington Senators 1915-33), born in Morocco, Indiana (d. 1974)

Antonio Massana, Spanish composer (Canigó), and Jesuit priest, born in Barcelona, Spain (d. 1966)

Feb 24 Marjorie Main [Mary Tomlinson], American vaudeville and screen actress (The Egg and I; Ma and Pa Kettle films; Another Thin Man), born near Acton, Indiana (d. 1975)

Dame Myra Hess, British concert pianist, born in London, England (d. 1955)

Joe Malone

Canadian Hockey HOF center (only player in NHL history to score 7 goals in a single game 1920; Stanley Cup 1912, 13 Quebec Bulldogs; 1924 Montreal Canadiens), born in Quebec City, Québec

Jan Duiker, Dutch architect (Zonnestral), born in The Hague, the Netherlands (d. 1935)

Oscar Egg, Swiss track and road bicycle racer (3 x world hour record), born in Schlatt, Switzerland (d. 1961)

Norman Bethune

Canadian doctor, communist and humanitarian (Spanish Civil War, Second Sino-Japanese War), born in Gravenhurst, Ontario

Fernand Ansseau, Belgian opera singer (Orfeo), born in Boussu-Bois, Belgium (d. 1972)

Oswald von Nell-Breuning, German theologist and philosopher, born in Trier, Germany (d. 1991)

Vyacheslav Molotov

Russian politician (Soviet Minister of Foreign Affairs, 1939-49, 1953-6), born in Kukarka, Russian Empire

Vannevar Bush, American engineer and science administrator (developed 1st electronic analogue computer), born in Everett, Massachusetts (d. 1974)

Evert Axel Taube, Swedish ballad singer and composer, born in Gothenburg, Sweden (d. 1976)

Mar 12 Vaslav Nijinsky, Ukrainian legendary ballet dancer (Petroesjka - Ballets Russes) and choreographer, born in Kyiv, Russian Empire (d. 1950) [OS=Feb 28]

Mar 12 William Dudley Pelley, American leader of the Silver Legion (d. 1965)

Fritz Busch, German conductor, born in Siegen, Province of Westphalia (d. 1951)

Mar 13 Michael Taube, Polish composer, born in Lodz, Poland (d. 1972)

Solomon Mikhoels, Soviet actor and chairman of the Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee (d. 1948)

Harold Morris, American composer, born in San Antonio Texas (d. 1964)

Philip Hands, South African cricket batsman (7 Tests, 2 x 50, HS 83; Western Province), born in Cape Town, South Africa (d. 1951)

Lauritz Melchior, Danish-American baritone tenor (National Symphony), born in Copenhagen, Denmark (d. 1973)

Agnes Macphail, Canadian politician (first women elected to Canada's House of Commons), born in Proton Township, Ontario (d. 1954) [1]

Mar 24 John Rock, American obstetrician and gynecologist who co-developed the 1st birth control pill, born in Marlborough, Massachusetts (d. 1984)

Jozef Arras, Flemish writer, born in Lier (d. 1919)

Paul Whiteman "The King of Jazz", American orchestra leader (George Gershwin's "Rhapsody In Blue"), born in Denver, Colorado (d. 1967)

Harold Spencer Jones, English astronomer and 10th astronomer royal of England whose work led to a more accurate determination of the distance between the Earth and the Sun, born in London (d. 1960)

(William) Lawrence Bragg, English physicist (Nobel Prize for Physics, 1915 - crystalline structure analysis by means of X-rays), born in Adelaide, Australia (d. 1971) [1]

Fie Carelsen [Sophia de Jong], Dutch stage and screen actress (Malle gevallen), born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1975)

André-Louis Danjon, French astronomer (invented Danjon astrolabe), born in Caen, France (d. 1967)

Anthony Fokker

Dutch aviation pioneer and aircraft manufacturer (Eindecker monoplanes, Fokker Triplane), born in Blitar, East Java, Dutch East Indies

Marjory Stoneman Douglas, American journalist, conservationist (1st Lady of the Everglades) and women's suffrage advocate, born in Minneapolis, Minnesota (d. 1998)

Apr 7 Victoria Ocampo, Argentine writer and publisher (Sur magazine), born in Buenos Aires, Argentina (d. 1979)

Donna Rachele Mussolini, wife of Italian dictator Benito Mussolini, born in Predappio, Romagna, Kingdom of Italy (d. 1979)

Frank Murphy, American politician and 56th United States Attorney General, born in Harbor Beach, Michigan (d. 1949)

Fred Root, English cricket fast bowler (3 Tests, 8 wickets; Derbyshire CCC, Worcestershire CCC), born in Somercotes, England (d. 1954)

Arthemus "Art" Acord, American silent film actor and rodeo champion (Arizona Kid, Hard Fists), born in Glenwood, Utah (d. 1931)

James Rennie, Canadian actor (Lash, Little Damozel), born in Toronto, Ontario (d. 1965)

Lou Bandy [Lodewijk Ferdinand Dieben], Dutch revue-artist (Look for the Sun), born in The Hague, Netherlands (d. 1959)

Adolf Schärf, Austrian politician (President of Austria, 1957-65; Vice-Chancellor, 1945-57), born in Nikolsburg, Moravia (now Mikulov, Czech Republic) (d. 1965)

Apr 20 Maurice Duplessis, 16th Premier of Quebec, born in Trois-Rivières, Quebec, Canada (d. 1959)

Donald Tweedy, American composer, and educator, born in Danbury, Connecticut (d. 1948)

Apr 23 Marcel L'Herbier, French director and screenwriter (El Dorado), born in Paris (d. 1979)

Edgar Kennedy, American silent and sound screen character actor famous for his 'slow burn' (Laurel & Hardy films; Duck Soup; "Average Man" shorts) and director (From Soup to Nuts), born in Lake San Antonio, California (d. 1948)

E. E. Smith, American food engineer and sci-fi author (Triplanetary), born in Sheboygan, Wisconsin (d. 1965)

Alex Pompez, American Baseball HOF executive (owner NgL Cuban Stars [East] 1923-28; NY Cubans 1935-51), born in Key West, Florida (d. 1974)

Christopher Morley, American author (Kitty Foil), born in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania (d. 1957)

Claire Whitney, American silent film actress (Blind Fools, Haunted Mine), born in New York City (d. 1969)

Billy House, American actor (Imitation of Life; Bedlam: The Egg and I), born in Mankato, Minnesota (d. 1961)

Alfred Jodl

German general during World War II (head of the German High Command, signed unconditional Nazi surrender), born in Würzburg, German Empire

Katherine Anne Porter, American writer (Ship of Fools), born in Indian Creek, Texas (d. 1980)

Philip James, American composer, and conductor (New Jersey Symphony, 1922-29; Bamberger Little Symphony, 1929-36), and educator (NYU, 1934-56), born in Jersey City, New Jersey (d. 1975)

Mary Charleson, Irish-American silent film actress (Upstairs And Down), born in Dungannon, Ireland (d. 1961)

Ho Chi Minh

Vietnamese communist revolutionary and President of North Vietnam (1946-69), born in Nghệ An Province, French Indochina

Beniamino Gigli, Italian lyric tenor (La Gioconde - "Enzo"; Metropolitan Opera, 1920-32), born in Recanati, Marche, Italy (d. 1957)

Albert van Raalte, Dutch conductor (AVRO - Dutch Radio Orchestra, 1928-40), born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1952)

Herbert Marshall, English actor (Trouble in Paradise; The Little Foxes), born in London (d. 1996)

Kurt Edzard, German sculptor (nudes/portraits), born in Bremen, Germany (d. 1972)

Fritzi Brunette, American actress, born in Savannah, Georgia (d. 1943)

Francis de Bourguignon, Belgian pianist (accompanist to Nellie Melba), and contemporary classical composer, born in Brussels, Belgium (d. 1961)

May 29 Martin Wickramasinghe, Sri Lankan author (Gamperaliya - The Uprooted/Changing Village), born in Koggala, British Ceylon (d. 1976)

Frank Morgan [Francis Wuppermann], American silent and sound film character actor (The Wizard of Oz; The Affairs of Cellini), born in New York City (d. 1949)

Dorothy Heyward, American playwright (Porgy), born in New York City (d. 1961)

Jun 6 Ted Lewis [Theodore Leopold Friedman], American entertainer, bandleader and musician ("Is Everybody Happy?"), born in Circleville, Ohio (d. 1971)

Leslie Banks, English actor and director (Jamaica Inn, 48 Hours), born in Liverpool, England (d. 1952)

Powell Weaver, American composer, born in Clearfield, Pennsylvania (d. 1951)

Jun 10 Sessue Hayakawa, Japanese actor (Bridge on River Kwai, Hell to Eternity), born in Minamibōsō, Chiba, Japan (d. 1973)

Egon Schiele, Austrian painter and graphic artist, born in Tulln an der Donau, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1918)

May Allison, American actress (A Fool There Was, Almost Married), born in Rising Fawn, Georgia (d. 1989)

Georg Wüst, German Oceanographer (provided first complete understanding of the temperature, salinity and deep-current structure of the Atlantic Ocean), born in Posen, Germany (d. 1977)

Stan Laurel

English comedian (Laurel & Hardy films), born in Ulverston, England

Barbara Everest, American actress (Fatal Witness, Inquest), born in London, England (d. 1968)

Cum Posey, American Baseball HOF executive (owner NgL Homestead Grays; 9 x consecutive NL pennants 1937–45); and Basketball HOF guard (5 x Coloured World C'ships), born in Homestead, Pennsylvania (d. 1946)

Jun 20 Dorothy Bernard, American stage, silent and sound screen actress (Life With Father - "Margaret"), born in Port Elizabeth, British Cape Colony (now South Africa) (d. 1955)

Frank Sherman Land, founder of the Order of DeMolay, born in Kansas City, Missouri (d. 1959)

Charlotte Greenwood, American actress (Oklahoma; Moon over Miami), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 1978)

Jun 25 Hans Marchwitza, German writer and communist, born in Scharley, Upper Silesia (d. 1965)

Jeanne Eagels, American actress and former Ziegfeld Girl (Rain, Under False Colors), born in Kansas City, Missouri (d. 1929)

Gertrude McCoy, American silent screen actress (Blue Bird), born in Sugar Valley, Georgia (d. 1967)

Jun 30 Horace Chapman, South African cricket all-rounder (2 Tests, 1 wicket; Natal), born in Durban, Natal (d. 1941)

Earl Roy Curry, American religious thinker and Kirtland Temple overseer, born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania (d. 1980)

Frederick Lewis Allen, American social historian and editor of Harper's Magazine, born in Boston, Massachusetts (d. 1954)

Andy Sandham, English cricket batsman (14 Tests; 1st triple centurion 325 v WI 1930), born in London, England (d. 1982)

Tom Powers, American actor (Station West, Destination Moon), born in Owensboro, Kentucky (d. 1955)

Walter Hasenclever, German expressionist poet and playwright (Der Sohn), born in Aachen, Germany (d. 1940)

André Souris, Belgian composer, born in Marchienne-au-Pont, Belgium (d. 1970)

Arthur Tedder, British air marshal (deputy commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force during Normandy landings WWII), born in Glenguin, Scotland (d. 1967)

Jul 11 Georg Annenkov, Russian-French artist and stage and film set designer ('The Mutiny of the Machines'), born in Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky, Russian Empire (d. 1974)

Ossip Zadkine [Zadkin], Russian French sculptor (Destroyed City), born in Vitsebsk, Russian Empire (d. 1967)

Charles Erwin Wilson, American engineer (President and CEO of General Motors) and politician (United States Secretary of Defense 1953-57), born in Minerva, Ohio (d. 1961)

Jul 18 Chick Evans, American golfer (US Open 1916), born in Indianapolis, Indiana (d. 1979)

Jul 18 Frank Forde, 15th Prime Minister of Australia (the shortest-serving prime minister in Australia's history-8 days), born in Mitchell, Queensland, Australia (d. 1983)

George II, King of Greece (1922-24 and 1935-47), born at Tatoi Palace in Parnitha, Kingdom of Greece (d. 1947)

Verna Felton, American actress (Cinderella, Sleeping Beauty, Lady and the Tramp, December Bride), born in Salinas, California (d. 1966)

Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy

American matriarch, mother of JFK, RFK & Ted, born in Boston, Massachusetts

Julian Rivero, American actor (Son of Oklahoma, Via Pony Express), born in San Francisco, California (d. 1976)

Jul 25 Tom O'Brien, American actor (Physical Evidence), born in San Diego, California (d. 1947)

Daniel J. Callaghan, US Admiral (Medal of Honor), born in San Francisco, California (d. 1942)

Judith Lowry, American actress (The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds), born in Fort Sill, Oklahoma (d. 1976)

Marie Lohr, Australian actress (Pygmalion, Small Hotel), born in Sydney, New South Wales (d. 1975)

Casey Stengel

American Baseball HOF outfielder (World Series 1921, 22 NY Giants) and manager (7 x World Series NY Yankees; NY Mets 1st manager), born in Kansas City, Missouri

Marin Sais, American actress (The Pony Express Girl), born in San Rafael, California (d. 1971)

Aug 2 Pauline Hall, Norwegian composer, born in Hamar, Hedmark, Norway (d. 1969)

Dolf Luque, Cuban Baseball HOF pitcher (World Series 1919, 33; MLB wins leader & MLB ERA leader 1923; Cincinnati Reds, NY Giants), born in Havana, Cuba (d. 1957)

Aug 4 Erich Weinert, German communist writer, born in Magdeburg (d. 1953)

Erich Kleiber, Austrian-Argentine conductor (Teatro Colón, 1937-49; NBC Symphony, 1947-48), born in Vienna, Austria-Hungary (d. 1956)

Aug 5 Hans Gál, Austrian-British composer (Die heilige Ente (The Sacred Duck)), born in Brunn am Gebirge, Austria (d. 1987)

Aug 5 Naum Gabo [Pevsner], Russian-American sculptor (Stillife Flower), born in Bryans, Russian Empire (d. 1977)

César Cortinas, Uruguayan composer, born in San José de Mayo, Uruguay (d. 1918)

Aug 9 Eino Kaila, Finnish psychologist and philosopher, born in Alajärvi, Finland (d. 1958)

Aug 9 Henech Kon. Polish composer and cabaret performer, born in Łódź, Kingdom of Poland (d. 1972)

Aug 9 Sándor Jemnitz, Hungarian composer, born in Budapest, Kingdom of Hungary, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1963)

Angus Lewis MacDonald, Canadian politician, Liberal premier of Nova Scotia (1933-40), born in Dunvegan, Nova Scotia (d. 1954)

Erich Wichman, Dutch fascist painter and sculptor, born in Utrecht, Netherlands (d. 1929)

Al Goodman, Russian-American orchestra leader (NBC Comedy Hour), born in Nikopol, Russia (d. 1972)

[Lavinia] Marian Fleming Poe, African American advocate in Virginia, born in Warwick, County, Virginia (d. 1974)

Elizabeth Bolden, American Supercentenarian (oldest verified person in the world at the time of her death), born in Somerville, Tennessee (d. 2006)

Aug 15 Elvin M. Jellinek, American physiologist and pioneer in the study of alcoholism, born in New York City (d. 1963)

Aug 15 Jacques Ibert, French composer (Escales), born in Paris, France (d. 1962)

Harry Hopkins, US politician, Secretary of Commerce under FDR (Loan & Lease law), born in Sioux City, Iowa (d. 1946)

Aug 17 Ralph Teetor, American automotive engineer (1st blind engineer in the US, inventor of cruise control), born in Hagerstown, Indiana (d. 1982) [1]

Aug 17 Stefan Bastyr, Polish pioneering aviator, first flight in independent Poland (d. 1920)

Maurice Podoloff, American attorney, professional sports administrator (AHL President, 1943-47; NBA President, 1946-63), and namesake of NBA regular season MVP Award, born in Yelisavetgrad, Russian Empire (now Ukraine) (d. 1985) [birth details unconfirmed]

Aug 18 Walther Funk, German economist and Nazi politician, born in Danzkehmen, Kingdom of Prussia, German Empire (d. 1960)

Yves Alix, French painter and graphic artist, born in Fontainebleau, France (d. 1969)

H. P. Lovecraft, American horror writer (At the Mountains of Madness, Weird Tales), born in Providence, Rhode Island (d. 1937)

Cecil Kellaway, South African-American stage and screen character actor (Guess Who's Coming to Dinner; The Luck of the Irish), born in Cape Town, Cape Colony (now South Africa) (d. 1973)

Aug 22 Floyd Henri Allport, American psychologist and sociologist, born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin (d. 1979)

Duke Kahanamoku, American swimmer, surfer (Olympic gold 100m freestyle 1912, 20; 4x200m freestyle relay 1920), born in Honolulu, Hawaii (d. 1968)

Aug 24 Franz Philipp, German composer, born in Freiburg im Breisgau, Germany (d. 1972)

Aug 24 Jean Rhys [Ella Gwendolyn Rees Williams], British writer (Voyage in the Dark), born in Roseau, Dominica (d. 1979)

Tommy Andrews, Australian cricketer (NSW & Aussie player of the 1920's), born in Newtown, Australia (d. 1970)

Man Ray, American artist and photographer (Dada), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 1976)

Ivor Gurney, English composer and poet, born in Gloucester (d. 1937)

Margaret Landis, American silent movie actress (A Million to Burn; The Empire Builders), born in Nashville, Tennessee (d. 1981)

Clara Kimball Young, American actress (Return of Chandu), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1960)

Sep 6 Manfred Gurlitt, German composer, born in Berlin, Germany (d. 1973)

Colonel Sanders

American founder of Kentucky Fried Chicken, born in Henryville, Indiana

Elsa Schiaparelli

Italian fashion designer, born in Rome, Italy

Franz Werfel, Austrian-Bohemian novelist, playwright, and poet (Mirror Man, The Forty Days of Musa Dagh), born in Prague, Austria-Hungary (d. 1945)

Sep 10 Mortimer Wheeler, British archaeologist who introduced scientific methods, born in Glasgow, Scotland (d. 1976)

Marius Ulfrstad, Norwegian composer, born in Ellingsøya< Norway (d. 1968)

Guido Guerrini, Italian composer, born in Faenza, Italy (d. 1965)

Agatha Christie

English crime writer (Murder on the Orient Express, Mousetrap), born in Torquay, Devon

Claude McKaye, Jamaican-American author (Songs of Jamaica, Banjo), born in Clarendon Parish, Jamaica (d. 1948)

Sep 15 Frank Martin, Swiss composer (In Terra Fax), born in Geneva, Switzerland (d. 1974)

Ernst Deutsch [Dorian], Jewish-Austrian actor (Moon is Down, 3rd Man), born in Prague, Bohemia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1969)

Gabriel Heatter, American radio commentator famous for his WWII sign-on "There's good news tonight", born in Brooklyn, New York (d. 1972)

Sep 17 Lubov Tchernicheva, Russian-British ballerina, born in St. Petersburg, Russia (d. 1976)

Vladimír Ambros, Czech composer, born in Prostějov, Czech Republic (d. 1956)

Rachel Bluwstein, Hebrew poet, born in Saratov, Imperial Russia (d. 1931)

Ferdinand Gonseth, Swiss mathematician and philosopher, born in Sonvilier, Switzerland (d. 1975)

Arthur Walter Kramer, American composer, born in New York City (d. 1969)

Friedrich Paulus

German field marshal who commanded the 6th Army at Stalingrad and was the highest-ranking German officer to surrender, born in Guxhagen, Germany

A. P. Herbert, English journalist and writer (Punch, Helen), born in Ashtead, Surrey, England (d. 1971)

Sep 24 Mike González, Cuban baseball player, born in Havana, Cuba (d. 1977)

Alice Joyce, American actress (Song O' My Heart), born in Kansas City, Missouri (d. 1955)

Oct 1 Constantin C. Nottara, Romanian violinist and composer (Peace Poem), born in Bucharest, Romania (d. 1951)

Oct 1 Stanley Holloway, English actor (Higgins-Our Man Higgins), born in London, England (d. 1982)
